thread.title: Walton football advances in Class D playoffs
thread.title_full: Walton football advances in Class D playoffs

title: Walton football advances in Class D playoffs
text:
Walton football advances in Class D playoffs Mary Rakas, mrakas@gannett.com | @Section4Scores 12:36 a.m. EDT October 25, 2015 Walton football advances in Class D playoffs Football. CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Senior running back Derek Mead ran for 89 yards and two touchdowns to lead host Walton to a 36-18 win over Harpursville/Afton in the first round of Class D playoffs on Saturday. 
Mead scored on a 15-yard rush to put the Warriors ahead 14-0 in the first quarter. He added a 53-yard touchdown rush in the fourth. 
Harpursville/Afton brought the score to 14-6 in the second quarter, after Josh Wilson scored on a nine-yard run. 
Walton answered right back, when Blake Hitt threw a 20-yard pass to Jordan Somers with 34 seconds left to extend the lead. 
“That was a big play for us,” said Walton coach Jim Hoover. “It put us up by two scores before the half.” 
Dawson Beers capped the scoring for the Warriors after recovering a fumble in the Harpursville/Afton end zone. 
Walton will play Tioga in a semifinal game on Saturday at Binghamton Alumni Stadium at noon. 
Susquehanna Valley 37, Oneonta 8: Host SV scored 37 unanswered points after an 8-0 deficit to win in section 4 over Oneonta. Kyle Novobilski led the way with 71 yards on the ground. 
Quarterback Cameron Manchester only completed three passes for 77 yards, but two of those resulted in scores for the Sabers. Alex Ewanow caught one of his passes in the third quarter for a touchdown, and Jason Moelder capped the scoring with a touchdown catch in the fourth. 
SV will travel to Chenango Valley this coming Saturday for the section 4 Class B semifinal. 
Newark Valley 47, Whitney Point 6: Chad Wright’s 78-yard interception return for a touchdown gave Newark Valley a 13-0 lead and sparked its offense as the Cardinals went soaring into the Class C sectional playoffs. 
Wright’s interception return came after a fumble by the Cardinal’s offense, and squashed Whitney Point’s momentum. 
Newark Valley (7-1) received tremendous praise from Whitney Point coach Mike Hakes calling the Cardinals “a very well coached team and a class act.” 
Hakes also gave credit the Nick Schermerhorn, saying, “He has a lot of the same traits as Vinnie Darpino. I like the way he controls their offense.” Schermerhorn ran for 35 yards and passed for 84 more and one touchdown. 
Newark Valley, their only loss to Class C’s top-ranked team Chenango Forks, will play the winner of Watkins Glen/O-M and Lansing for the Class C semifinal next Saturday. 
Nick Cannon contributed. Read or Share this story: http://press.sn/1N0gL84 TOP VIDEOS
